topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny frames the episode around how AI models improve via expert feedback and data work, introduces Jason Droege’s background (Scour, Uber Eats, Scale AI), and previews topics including the Meta deal and Scale’s role in training data and evals.

topics.title: Scour lessons: everything is negotiable
topics.summary: Jason recounts co-founding Scour with Travis Kalanick, learning early that business has no fixed playbook and that negotiation and incentives shape outcomes.

topics.title: Scour shutdown and the lawsuit reality check
topics.summary: Jason explains how Scour’s P2P sharing led to a massive lawsuit (settled for $1M), reinforcing how incumbents use legal pressure and how the “real world” operates.

topics.title: Scale AI after Meta’s $14B investment
topics.summary: Jason clarifies the Meta transaction structure (49% non-voting, no new board seat, limited employee transfers), Scale’s independence, and the company’s current business health and growth.

topics.title: From basic labeling to expert data work
topics.summary: They discuss how the market shifted from simple preference tasks to complex expert-driven work (PhDs, professionals), and Jason argues Scale has evolved alongside model needs rather than being stuck in “low-cost generalist labeling.”

topics.title: Recruiting and retaining scarce expert contributors
topics.summary: Jason describes how Scale finds experts via referrals, campus programs, and traditional sourcing, emphasizing that a strong contributor experience drives the best network effects.

topics.title: Reinforcement learning environments for AI agents
topics.summary: Jason explains RL environments as sandboxes for training agents to operate in real systems (e.g., Salesforce), highlighting the challenge of generalizing across endless permutations of configurations and tasks.

topics.title: What training data looks like in practice
topics.summary: They get concrete about data formats (artifacts plus rationale/annotations) and discuss how tasks vary depending on whether the goal is generation, debugging, or decision support.

topics.title: Enterprise AI: healthcare workflow and judgment digitization
topics.summary: Jason shares a healthcare example where AI summarizes large patient records and flags critical issues (e.g., allergy/medication conflicts), arguing that enterprises increasingly need organization-specific labeling to encode local judgment and context.

topics.title: How long will humans stay in the loop?
topics.summary: Jason argues data work is a “history of new beginnings,” expecting ongoing human contribution as new skills and knowledge emerge; he’s skeptical of near-term white-collar displacement and emphasizes human adaptability.

topics.title: Evals: defining what “good” looks like
topics.summary: They unpack evals as benchmarks for quality—especially in enterprise/government—discussing probabilistic systems, when “good” differs from “correct,” and why high-accuracy workflows are hardest to automate.

topics.title: Where AI is heading: from knowing to doing
topics.summary: Jason predicts the next wave is models taking actions via agents operating in real environments; within 2–3 years, tech capability may outpace organizational change management and policy readiness.

topics.title: Enterprise AI reality: pilots, hype, and timelines
topics.summary: Jason explains why many enterprise POCs stall: getting from 60–70% to production-grade reliability takes 6–12 months plus approvals and change management; the value is real but harder to operationalize than demos suggest.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Mercury, highlighting banking features for startups and businesses (wires, spend tracking, cards, invoicing, bill pay, reimbursements, capital).

topics.title: Customer obsession and incentives-driven product discovery
topics.summary: Jason describes his approach to customer conversations—probing underlying incentives rather than literal requests—and shares an early Uber Eats example where the team reverse-engineered restaurant unit economics to find a viable pricing/value model.
